children: Rocky Mountain spotted fever is a tick-borne rickettsial infection most prevalent in the southeastern and south central states. Look for a history of tick bite and recent travel to an endemic area; febrile illness in spring and summer months; and symptoms such as nausea, myalgia, dyspnea, cough, and headache. Also look for a macular rash starting on the ankles and wrists and often affecting the palms and soles of the feet; lesions spread centripetally and become petechial.
The Rocky Mountain spotted fever rash may not be present until 3 days after onset of illness.
Thrombocytopenia and elevated aminotransferase levels are characteristic. Serology is negative during acute infection. Immunohistochemistry or
of a skin biopsy specimen allows diagnosis at the time of acute infection.
Empiric treatment is often necessary. Select doxycycline. In patients who are pregnant, choose chloramphenicol. Nonresponse in 72 hours suggests an alternative diagnosis.
